name: Glen E. Rodgers
title: Traveling with the Atom: A Scientific Guide to Europe and Beyond
blurb: In Traveling with the Atom you will visit homesteads, graveyards, laboratories, apartments, abbeys, castles, and even a temple. You will be guided to picturesque villages as well as elegant and romantic cities in Europe that celebrate the lives and minds of great atomic thinkers

name: Erika Lorraine Milam
title: Creatures of Cain: The Hunt for Human Nature in Cold War America
blurb: Drawing on a wealth of archival materials and in-depth interviews, Milam charts the rise and precipitous fall in Cold War America of a theory that attributed early humanity's evolutionary success to their (purported) unique capacity for murder.

name: Peder J. Anker
title: The Power of the Periphery: How Norway Became an Environmental Pioneer for the World
blurb: This book is exploring the role of Norwegian scholar-activists of the late twentieth century portrayed Norway as a place of environmental stability in a world filled with tension. Norway's power, they argued, lay in the pristine, ideal natural environment of the periphery. Open Access - FREE

name: John M. Krige
title: How Knowledge Moves. Writing the Transnational History of Science and Technology
blurb: This book takes the content of knowledge itself as the object of transnational analysis, and uses about a dozen case studies to show how it is denied, selectively appropriated, and refashioned as it crosses borders in a world of interstate rivalry and multilateral collaboration.

name: Carolyn A. Cobbold
title: A Rainbow Palate: How Chemical Dyes Changed the West's Relationship with Food
blurb: Rainbow Palate – how chemical dyes changed our food - a cautionary tale about the unintended consequences of cutting edge science and how chemists lost control of their science

name: David Lindsay Roberts
title: Republic of Numbers: Unexpected Stories of Mathematical Americans Through History
blurb: This book recounts the life stories of a diverse set of Americans, illustrating the evolution of mathematical activity in this country over more than 200 years. It should appeal to anyone interested in mathematics or American history or both. Use the code HTWN to save 20%

name: Michael D. Gordin
title: Einstein in Bohemia
blurb: Einstein in Bohemia starts with the encounter of Albert Einstein and the city of Prague — where he lived and taught physics from April 1911 to August 1912 — and then follows his interactions amid the cultural ferment of late Habsburg Prague.

name: Jaipreet Virdi
title: Hearing Happiness: Deafness Cures in History
blurb: Through lyrical history and personal memoir, Hearing Happiness raises pivotal questions about deafness in American society and the endless quest for a cure—a harmful legacy that is still present in contemporary biomedicine. HSS discount code for 30% off:  EX56719

name: He Bian
title: Know Your Remedies: Pharmacy and Culture in Early Modern China
blurb: A cultural history of the concept of pharmacy, both the material nature of drugs and the trade in medicine, in early modern China. He Bian (@bowarrowstreet)'s new book provides a panoramic inquiry into China’s early modern cultural transformation through the lens of pharmacy.

name: Soraya de Chadarevian
title: Heredity under the Microscope: Chromosomes and the Study of the Human Genome
blurb: For much of the second half of the twentieth century pictures of orderly paired chromosomes were the most recognizable images of genetics. Heredity under the Microscope follows their use in and out of the laboratory and their role in discussions on heredity in humans. For 30% exhibit discount go to www.press.uchicago.edu/directmail and use keycode EX56720

name: Marilyn Fischer
title: Jane Addams's Evolutionary Theorizing: Constructing Democracy and Social Ethics
blurb: Can social evolutionary theorizing be ethical? Was Jane Addams really a scientist? Yes! Read how in one jargon-free book, Jane Addams's Evolutionary Theorizing: Constructing Democracy and Social Ethics, by Marilyn Fischer. Discount Code: UCPNEW

name: Olival Freire Junior
title: David Bohm - A Life Dedicated to Understanding the Quantum World
blurb: Some people considered Bohm’s work on the foundations of quantum mechanics worthless while others saw Bohm’s work on quantum mechanics and philosophy as a panacea. Both were wrong. This biography shows his attempts to understand the quantum, a quest he left unfinished.

name: Lara Freidenfelds
title: The Myth of the Perfect Pregnancy: A History of Miscarriage in America
blurb: A history of how Americans came to have unrealistic expectations that every pregnancy could be made perfect, and how even early pregnancy losses came to be devastating for many women. Includes STS analyses of ultrasound, pregnancy tests, embryo development timelines, and more. Order online at www.oup.com/academic with promo code AAFLYG6 to save 30%

name: Bill Jenkins
title: Evolution before Darwin: Theories of the Transmutation of Species in Edinburgh, 1804–1834
blurb: This book is the first major study of what was probably the most important centre or pre-Darwinian evolutionary thought in the British Isles. It sheds new light on the genesis and development of one of the most important scientific theories in the history of western thought.

name: Viktoria Tkaczyk, Mara Mills, and Alexandra Hui (eds.)
title: Testing Hearing. The Making of Modern Aurality
blurb: "Testing Hearing: The Making of Modern Aurality" considers both the testing of hearing and testing with hearing to explore the co-creation of modern epistemic and auditory cultures. Viktoria Tkaczyk, Mara Mills, and Alexandra Hui (eds.), Testing Hearing. The Making of Modern Aurality (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2020), online: https://oxford.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.1093/oso/9780197511121.001.0001/oso-9780197511121

name: Vanessa Heggie
title: Higher and Colder: A History of Extreme Physiology and Exploration
blurb: Higher and Colder tells the history of a neglected modern science (physiology) in a neglected space (the field), and in so doing offers new insight into how scientific authority is established in a complex, global world via an often dangerous, gendered and racialised practice

name: Ann Pizzorusso
title: Leonardo da Vinci Cartographer and Inventor of the Google Map
blurb: Leonardo da Vinci invented the Google Map. Publisher will offer the ebook free on October 10, 2020. To access the offer go to the Amazon.com site.

name: Ray Douglas Hurt
title: The Green Revolution in the Global South: Science, Politics, and Unintended Consequences
blurb: This is a survey of the Green Revolution from the early 1940s to the present. In it, I discuss the development, benefits, and consequences of the Green Revolution in Mexico, India and Pakistan, China, Southeast Asia, and Sub-Sahara Africa.

name: Carla Bittel, Elaine Leong, Christine von Oertzen (eds.)
title: Working With Paper: Gendered Practices in the History of Knowledge
blurb: In this book, we examine the history and materiality of paperstuff to unlock a new history of knowledge. We uncover the intricate negotiations of gender and power underlying both learned and quotidian practices, showing how paper matters beyond the page. Use code HSS20 to get a discount of 30% for online purchase via the PUP website.

name: James C. Ungureanu
title: Science, Religion, and the Protestant Tradition: Retracing the Origins of Conflict
blurb: My book revisits the origins, development, and popularization of the "conflict thesis," the idea that science and religion are in fundamental conflict. But in my book I argue that the “conflict thesis” was one of the many unintended consequences of the Protestant Reformation.

name: Susanne Bauer, Martina Schlünder, and Maria Rentetzi (eds.)
title: Boxes: A Field Guide
blurb: A book full of boxes. A box in itself. An unboxing. Gathered in the format of a field guide, this collation of essays offers an introduction to ways of ordering the world, unpacking their boxed-up, largely invisible politics and epistemics. Available as paperback and fully open access (PDF, ePub, Kindle) at: https://www.matteringpress.org/books/boxes

name: Sophie Brockmann
title: The Science of Useful Nature in Central America: Landscapes, Networks and Practical Enlightenment, 1784–1838
blurb: Scientific knowledge drawn from local networks and global Enlightenment thought was key to shaping the modern nations of Central America. SUNCA2020 20% discount

name: Steven R. Gullberg
title: Astronomy of the Inca Empire: Use and Significance of the Sun and the Night Sky
blurb: Astronomy in the Inca Empire was a robust and fundamental practice. Through modern archaeoastronomy and imagery this book helps to recover and interpret fascinating elements of Inca civilization. Over 300 images - with more than 260 in color - are included throughout the book.

name: Rachel Emma Rothschild
title: Poisonous Skies: Acid Rain and the Globalization of Pollution
blurb: Grounded in archival research spanning eight countries and five languages, as well as interviews with leading scientists from both government and industry, Poisonous Skies is the first book to examine the history of acid rain in an international context.

name: Simon Werrett
title: Thrifty Science: Making the Most of Materials in Early Modern Experiment
blurb: Thrifty Science explores the distinctive culture of domestic experiment in the early modern period and demonstrates how the values of the household helped to shape an array of experimental inquiries.

name: David Sepkoski
title: Catastrophic Thinking: Extinction and the Value of Diversity from Darwin to the Anthropocene
blurb: Why do we care about biological and cultural diversity, and why do we fear its loss? Catastrophic Thinking argues that we can answer these questions only by understanding the way extinction has been understood as a cultural and scientific concept over the past 200 years. To order books from this meeting online, go to www.press.uchicago.edu/directmail and use keycode EX56720 to apply the 30% exhibit discount.  This will allow you to purchase the book for the discounted price of $24.50.

name: Neeraja Sankaran
title: Leeuwenhoek's Legatees and Beijerinck's Beneficiaries: A History of Medical Virology in The Netherlands
blurb: Traveling from laboratory to laboratory, Leeuwenhoek’s Legatees and Beijerinck’s Beneficiaries follows the history of medical virology in the Netherlands and former Dutch colonies. As such, it shows the diverse and international character of medical research in the 20th century. Free (Open access) PDF version of book available through this link: https://library.oapen.org/handle/20.500.12657/22972.

name: Emmanuel Didier
title: America by the Numbers. Quantification, Democracy, and the Birth of National Statistics
blurb: A book about the intertwining of National statistics and politicizes in the US in the XXth c. How random sampling is inherently tied to the New Deal.  How statisticians had to become detectives and anthropologists, searching for elements that would help them portray America.

name: Sherrie Lynne lyons
title: From Cells to Organisms, Re-Envisioning Cell Theory
blurb: Thomas Huxley's critique of cell theory provides the scaffolding for an exploration of how cell theory shaped research and that results are interpreted not only through the lens of a microscope, but  through the lens of particular ideas and prior philosophical convictions. To request exam or desk copies of From Cells to Organisms or any other UTP title, please email requests@utorontopress.com and be sure to include the course name and number, start date, and estimated enrollment.

name: Edited By James Mussell and Graeme Gooday
title: A Pioneer of Connection: Recovering the Life and Work of Oliver Lodge
blurb: How did Oliver Lodge (1851-1940) become one of the most widely read scientists in his lifetime? Empathic connections with his audiences on shared human concerns informed his communication of physics,  technology, well-being and the after-life. Therein lay his public authority.

name: Matthew Shindell
title: The Life and Science of Harold C. Urey
blurb: Harold C. Urey (1893–1981) rose to fame alongside the prestige of 20th C American science. This biography examines the life and career of this enigmatic figure as a way of understanding changes in the social and intellectual landscape of American science, politics, and religion.

name: Margaret E. Schotte
title: Sailing School: Navigating Science and Skill, 1550-1800
blurb: This comparative study of how early modern sailors learned the science of navigation takes us into classrooms, bookstores, and examination halls, as well as onto ships’ decks. Navigators' manuscripts show how they relied on both theory *and* practice to succeed at sea. Use code HTWN for 30% off.

name: James Rodger Fleming
title: FIRST WOMAN: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere
blurb: My new book, First Woman: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere is about Joanne’s personal and professional life, her career prospects as a woman in science, and her relationship to the tropical atmosphere. My new book, First Woman: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere is about Joanne’s personal and professional life, her career prospects as a woman in science, and her relationship to the tropical atmosphere. Use promo code ASPROMP8 for a 30% discount

name: Jennifer L. Derr
title: The Lived Nile: Environment, Disease, and Material Colonial Economy in Egypt
blurb: From the microscopic to the regional, the local to the imperial, The Lived Nile traces the history and centrality of the environment in Egypt to questions of politics, knowledge, and the lived experience of the human body itself.

name: Andrew Fiss
title: Performing Math: A History of Communication and Anxiety in the American Mathematics Classroom
blurb: "Performing Math: A History of Communication and Anxiety in the American Mathematics Classroom" by Andrew Fiss, new from Rutgers University Press! Civil-War-Era student performances - plus classroom expectations for students' reading, writing, speaking about math - equals fun!

name: Hannah Marcus
title: Forbidden Knowledge: Medicine, Science, and Censorship in Early Modern Italy
blurb: Forbidden Knowledge takes us deep into the world of medicine and science in 16th and 17th-century Italy to reveal how physicians and censors navigated the uneven terrain between religious censorship and scientific utility in the age of Galileo. Order from the Press website and enter UCPNEW at checkout for 20% off.

name: Robin W. Scheffler
title: A Contagious Cause: The American Hunt for Cancer Viruses and the Rise of Molecular Medicine
blurb: The hunt for a human cancer virus was one of the largest peacetime biomedical research efforts in twentieth century America. Though this effort was fruitless, it foraged important connections between laboratory and legislature that profoundly shaped our understanding of life. Order at the University of Chicago Website with the 20% discount code UCPNEW, or watch the video for information on a free giveaway!

name: Etienne Benson
title: Surroundings: A History of Environments and Environmentalisms
blurb: What does it mean to “protect the environment”? Who counts as an “environmentalist”? This book shows how and why certain groups of people have embraced the concept of environment over the past two centuries and describes some of the new environmentalisms emerging today.

name: Stephen P. Weldon
title: The Scientific Spirit of American Humanism
blurb: The story of how prominent humanists---scientists, philosophers, and liberal intellectuals---across the twentieth-century embraced a science-centered idealism in their effort to reform American religious and secular institutions and promote a more democratic, rational society. The publisher is offering a 30% discount with the code HTWN.

name: Jennifer M. Rampling
title: The Experimental Fire: Inventing English Alchemy, 1300-1700
blurb: The Experimental Fire follows the attempts of English alchemists over four centuries to decipher the texts and reconstruct the practices of past adepts—in the process, reinventing alchemy as a distinctively “English” tradition, supported by royal patronage.

name: Janet Vertesi
title: Shaping Science: Organizations, Decisions, and Culture on NASA’s Teams
blurb: Drawing on a decade of comparative research with NASA's robotic spacecraft teams, Vertesi shows us how understanding scientific organizations is the key to unlocking the relationship between knowledge and social order.

name: Mark Solovey
title: Social Science for What? Battles over Public Funding for the "Other Sciences" at the National Science Foundation
blurb: This study of the battles over public funding is crucial for understanding the recent history of the social sciences as well as ongoing debates over their scientific status and social value. OPEN ACCESS VERSION is available - FREE - on the publisher's website: https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/social-science-what Also, get the downloadable timeline on the left-hand side, under Reader's Resources.

name: B. Harun Küçük
title: Science without Leisure: Practical Naturalism in Istanbul, 1660-1732
blurb: Science without Leisure explains how science in the Ottoman Empire ultimately became the domain of physicians, bureaucrats, and engineers rather than of scholars and philosophers.

name: Ainissa Ramirez
title: The Alchemy of Us: How Humans and Matter Transformed One Another
blurb: In the bestselling tradition of "Stuff Matters" and "The Disappearing Spoon"--a clever and engaging look at materials, the innovations they made possible, and how these technologies changed us.
